subsection.title: Average Speed
subsection.p:
Perhaps the crudest measure of how fast something has been moving is to look at how much distance it has covered in how much time. The ratio of distance convered, d , and time taken, t , is called the average speed . We will denote average speed by the symbol v_{s,\text{av}}.
v_{s,\text{av}} = \dfrac{d}{t}.
Suppose you drive a car for a distance of 4000\text{ km} in 50\text{ hr}. Then your average speed will be
v_{s,\text{av}} = \dfrac{4000\text{ km}}{50\text{ hr}} = 80\text{ km/hr}.

exercise.title: Constant Speed Warmup

statement.p: You drive your car from New York City to Los Algeles in 50 h at an average speed of 96 km/h. What is the total distance you have traveled?

hint.p: Use the definition of average speed.

exercise.solution:
From the definition of average speed, v = d/t , we get
d = v t = 96 \text{ km/h } \times 50 \text{ h } = 4,800 \text{ km}.

subsection.title: Average Velocity
subsection.p: Another measure of motion focuses, not on all the places you went during an interval, but where you were at the beginning and where you ended up at the end, i.e., we care about displacement during the interval and not the distance covered. Average velocity is obtained by dividing the displacment by the interval.

If the motion is on the x axis, we will denote the average velocity by the symbol v_{\text{av},x}, which will be the ratio of the displacement, \Delta x , and the time interval, \Delta t .
v_{\text{av},x} = \dfrac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}.

sidebyside.p: Suppose you go from one end A of the room to another end B, say 3\text{ m} from A, and then track back 1\text{ m} to C. Suppose you use positive x axis in the direction A-to-B. You would have covered a distance

subsection.p:
d = 3 + 1 = 4\text{ m},
but your displacemnt would be
\Delta x = 2\text{ m},
since tracking back canceled out part of the original displacement and you ended up at x = 2\text{ m} from the starting place A. Now, say A-to-B-to-C took 5\text{ sec}, then your average velocity and average speed will be
\amp v_{\text{av},x} = \dfrac{2}{5} = 0.4\text{ m/s}, \amp v_{s,\text{av}} = \dfrac{4}{5} = 0.8\text{ m/s}.

remark.p: If there was no turn back in the motion, as in the A-to-B part of your motion, we would get the same absolute values for the displacement and the distance traveled, and hence, same absolute value of the average velocity and the average speed. Their equality will always be the case if the time interval is small enough that there is no scope of a turnaround in the motion.

For instance, in the case of mathematically infinitersimal time interval, meaning as small as you like except zero. Using this idea, we next define a special type of average velocity, called the instantaneous velocity, whose magnitude will always be equal to the speed at that instant. An alternative to the infinitesimal picture for the instantaneous velocity is to use a graphical definition, which we discuss now.

statement.p: A ball is rolling on a straight track. At the end of the track, the ball hits a wall and bounces back with the same speed. Ignore the time the ball was in contact with the wall during the collision. Let the original direction of ball be the positive x axis direction. Let the ball be at x = 15\text{ cm} at t = 0 , and at x = 75\text{ cm} at t = 10\text{ sec} . The wall is at x = 100\text{ cm}. What are (a) the average velocity and (b) average speed during the t = 0 to t = 10\text{ sec} interval?

hint.p: Average velocity is based on coordinates and average speed is based on actual distance covered.

solution.p: (a) Average Velocity : For the sake of brevity, we will drop the coordinate subscript x from the symbols.

The definition of average velocity for a one-dimensional motion on x axis is
v_{av} = \dfrac{\Delta x }{\Delta t}.
Therefore,
v_{av} = \dfrac{75\text{ cm} - 15\text{ cm}}{10\text{ sec}} = 6 \text{ cm/s}.
(a) Average Speed

The definition of average speed for any motion is
v_{s,av} = \dfrac{d }{\Delta t}.
The motion has two legs here: (1) from x = 15\text{ cm} to x = 100\text{ cm} (i.e., the wall) and (2) from x = 100\text{ cm} to x = 75\text{ cm} . We need to add these distances, not just difference in coordinates. Therefore,
v_{s,av} = \dfrac{85\text{ cm} + 25\text{ cm}}{10\text{ sec}} = 11 \text{ cm/s}.

subsection.title: Instantaneous Velocity
subsection.p: Often we want velocity at a particular instant. What we mean by this is the average velocity between that instant, say t and an instant very close to t, e.g., a tiny amount of time later than t, which we can indicate by t + \Delta t . How close to t should the instant t + \Delta t be? The answer is as close to t as possible. This is the notion of infintesimal interval.

Denoting instantaneous velocity for a motion along the x axis by symbol v_x , we write this special averaging formally as
v_x = \dfrac{x\left(\text{at } (t+\Delta t)\right) - x\left(\text{at } t\right)}{\Delta t},
for t+\Delta t as close to t as possible. Since v_x is a ratio of a change in x to a change in t it can be computed by the slope of x versus t plot. The as close as possible is more precisely implemented in Calculus by the concept of taking \Delta t \rightarrow 0 limit, which makes v_x a derivative.

Note that v_x positive would mean the object is moving towards the positive x axis and v_x negative would mean the object is moving towards the negagive x axis. This is clear from the sign of the numerator of Eq. relative to the denominator; say, t + \Delta t is an instant later than t , then, if you went a little bit to the right, your numerator would be positive, giving v_x\gt 0, and if you went a little bit to the left, your numerator would be negative, giving v_x \lt 0.

The requirement that t+\Delta t be as close to t as possible makes the turn around in motion between t and t+\Delta t impossible. That means, the magnitude of instantaneous velocity will also be the speed at that instant, i.e., the instantaneous speed, which we will denote by symbol v without x. Thus, while v_x can be positive or negative, v will always be positive.

subsection.title: Graphical Definition of Velocity
subsection.p: If you tell me where an object is at all times, i.e., give me the function x(t) , then, that gives me a complete picture of the motion. The instantaneous velocity at instant t is the rate at which x is changing at t. If the object was moving steadily, as between B and C in , you would find that the plot of x versus t is a straight line with the slope equal to the rate at which x is changing. Thus, we come to the following observation:

But, what happens if the motion is not steady, but slows, as between A and B in or speeds up as between C and D in ? The plot of x versus t is now curved. A curved plot does not have a slope! We now work with tangent to the curve at the instant we want the velocity.

figure.caption: is reproduced here to illustrate the computation of velocity by slope of tangent line to the x versus t plot.

subsection.p: In the curved part of x versus t, we obtain instantaneous velocity from the slope of the tangent line at the point of interest. Say, we want the velocity at D in . We will then draw a tangent to the curve at this point. The slope of the tangent PQ at point D of the curve equals the instantaneous velocity v_x at D.

You can see that between A and B, the absolute value of slopes of tangent lines are getting smaller - hence motion is slowing down. The slopes at various instants between C and D will convince you that their slopes are getting larger, hence the motion is speeding up.

Figure shows an x versus t plot that has two linear segments. We get two different velocity values in the two linear segments from their slopes. In the figure, the two linear segments appear to meet at one point, but that is just an artefact. In reality, this cannot be the case, since that would give two different values of velocity at the point the two linear segments meet.

figure.caption: The slope of x versus t plot gives the velocity v_x . Since the plot has two linear segments, there will be two velociy values (i) for 0\lt t \lt 20\text{ sec}, v_x = 300/20 = 15\text{ m/s}, and (ii) for 20\text{ sec}\lt t \lt 70\text{ sec}, v_x = -400/50 = -8\text{ m/s}. Note the velocity v_x in the second segment is negative since the object is moving towards negative x axis. The speed in the first segment is v_s = 15\text{ m/s} and in the second segment v_s = 8\text{ m/s}, without the sign.

example.title: Instantaneous Velocity from Curved x vs t Graph
example.p: The x coordinate of a runner plotted against time t as in the figure below.

We draw a tangent to the x versus t graph at the instant, here t = 20 sec, we want the velocity. The slope of the tangent line gives the numerical value of the x-velocity. Here x-velocity is positive since the runner's x coordinate is increasing with time. That is, velocity has magnitude 4.0 m/s in the positivr x direction.
You can see that the slope of the tangent has different value at different instants. Try looking at the slope at other times. This is a situation in which velocity v_x is changing with time.

statement.p: A train is moving on a straight track. Taking the track to be the x axis, the position of the train was noted at various times. The data was then plotted with t along the abscissa and x along the ordinate as shown in . What are the values of v_x at the following instants (a) t = 0 sec, (b) t = 10 sec, (c) t = 25 sec, (d) t = 35 sec, (e) t = 50 sec, and (f) t = 70 sec?

hint.p: Read off two nearby points on the graph and compute the slope.

solution.p: (a) Note that at t = 0 , the slope is not zero if we assume that the line contnues past t = 0 to the negative time. To determine v_x here, you read off two nearby points on the graph. For t = 0 , we will use (t_1,x_1) = (0, 0) and (t_2,x_2) = (20\text{ s}, 100\text{ m}) . From these we get v_x at t=0 .
(b) For t = 10 sec, we take points at t = 0 and t = 20 sec. We get the same value as in (a).
(c) For t = 25 sec, we take points at t = 20 sec and t = 30 sec, viz., (t_1,x_1) = (20 \text{ s}, 100 \text{ m}) and (t_2,x_2) = (30\text{ s}, 300 \text{ m}) . From these we get v_x at t = 25 sec.
(d) There is no change in x around this time point. So, v_x = 0 at t = 35 sec.
(e) For t = 50 sec, we take points at t = 40 sec and t = 60 sec, viz., (t_1,x_1) = (40 \text{ s}, 300 \text{ m}) and (t_2,x_2) = (60\text{ s}, 0 ) . From these we get v_x at t = 50 sec.
Note that v_x here is negative. This is due to the fact that the train is moving in the same direction as the negative x axis.
(f) There is no change in x around this time point. Therefore, v_x = 0 here.

subsection.title: Displacement from Velocity Graphically
subsection.p: We saw above that we can get velocity from the slope of tangent to the plot of x versus t , avoiding the need to take the derivative of the function x(t) .

A similar thing happens also on the reverse process - obtaining displacement from velocity. We start with a plot of v_x versus t. Then, the area between the v_x plot and the v_x = 0 line is equal to the displacement.

p.men: \Delta x \equiv x(t_f) - x(t_i) = \text{Area under the }v_x\text{ verus } t\text{ plot.}

figure.caption: The area under the curve to get \Delta x from v_x versus t plot. The area for the curve when v_x \gt 0 is positive, as between t=0 and t= 2\text{ sec} and the area for the curve when v_x \lt 0 is negative, as between t= 2\text{ sec} and t= 4\text{ sec}.

example.title: Displacement \Delta x from a v_x vs t Graph

statement.p: The instantaneous v_x of a car moving on a straight road is plotted against time t as shown in .
Find the displacements of x coordinates of the car during the following intervals of time:
Note that area can be negative here corresponding to x_f - x_i \lt 0 .

hint.p: For each interval find the area between the curve and the abscissa (i.e., the time axis).

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) We wish to find the area under the curve between t = 0 and t = 20 \text{ s} - the shaded area in . This is just the area of the triangle with base = 20 sec, and height = 20 m. Therefore,
x_f - x_i = \dfrac{1}{2} \times 20 \text{ m/s} \times 20 \text{ s} = 200 \text{ m}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) We wish to find the area under the curve between t = 20 \text{ s} and t = 40 \text{ s} in . This is sum of areas of two triangles, a triangle above the time axis (where v_x \gt 0 ) and another below the time axis (where v_x \lt 0 ). The area of the triangle with v_x \gt 0 will give positive area and the other one will give negative area. They happen to cancel out.
x_f - x_i = \dfrac{1}{2} \times 20 \text{ m/s} \times 10 \text{ s} + \dfrac{1}{2} \times (-20) \text{ m/s} \times 10 \text{ s} = 0\text{ m}.
This means that the car went 100 m towards positive x axis and then backtracked same amount, ending up at the same x at the end as at the beginning.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) We wish to find the area under the curve between t = 40 \text{ s} and t = 70 \text{ s} as shown in . This is actually the area above the curve since the area of interest is the area between the curve and the abscissa of the plot.
x_f - x_i = \times (-20) \text{ m/s} \times 30 \text{ s} = -600\text{ m}.

exercise.title: Compute \Delta x from v_x versus t plot

statement.p: From the v_x versus t plot in , find the changes in x during the following intervals in seconds (a) (0, 2) , (b) (2, 3) , (c) (3, 4) , and (d) (0, 4) .

solution.p:
(a) This is a rectangular area, of height 4\text{ m/s} and width 2\text{ sec}. The line is above the v_x = 0 line. Therefore, the change in x will be:
\Delta x = 4\text{ m/s} \times 2\text{ s} = 8\text{ m}.

(b) This is triangular area, of height 4\text{ m/s} and base 1\text{ sec}. The line is above the v_x = 0 line. Therefore, the change in x will be:
\Delta x = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 4\text{ m/s} \times 1\text{ s} = 2\text{ m}.

(c) This is triangular area, of height 2\text{ m/s} and base 1\text{ sec}. The line is below the v_x = 0 line. Therefore, the change in x will be:
\Delta x = -\dfrac{1}{2}\times 2\text{ m/s} \times 1\text{ s} = -1\text{ m}.

(d) This is just the sum of all the areas in (a), (b), and (c).
\Delta x = 8\text{ m} + 2\text{ m} -1\text{ m} = 9\text{ m}.

Find the displacements of the car during the following intervals of time: (a) t = 0 \rightarrow 20 \text{ s}, (b) t = 20 \text{ s}\rightarrow 40 \text{ s}, (c) t = 40 \text{ s}\rightarrow 50 \text{ s}, (d) t = 50 \text{ s}\rightarrow 70 \text{ s}, and (e) t = 10 \text{ s}\rightarrow 20 \text{ s}.

hint.p: Find the areas between the plot line and the time axis.

solution.p: The area under the plot (or, over the plot if v_x \lt 0) is the displacement. We use area of triangle = \dfrac{1}{2} \times base \times height and area of a rectangle = base \times height.
(a) \Delta x = 0.5 \times 20 \text{ s} \times 20 \text{ m/s} = 200 \text{ m}.
(b) \Delta x = 0.5 \times 20 \text{ s} \times 20 \text{ m/s} = 200 \text{ m}.
(c) \Delta x = 0.5 \times 10 \text{ s} \times (-10 \text{ m/s} ) = -50 \text{ m}.
(d) \Delta x = 20 \text{ s} \times (-10 \text{ m/s} ) = -200 \text{ m}.
(e) This one is different - here we need to add two parts, one a triangle and the other a square.

p.m: \Delta x = 0.5 \times 10 \text{ s} \times 10 \text{ m/s} + 10 \text{ s} \times (10 \text{ m/s} ) = 150 \text{ m}.

p.p:
The fundamental definition of v_x , the rate of change of x is based on the observation in Calculus that derivative of a function is equal to the slope of the tangent line. Therefore, we define v_x as derivative of x versus t .
v_x = \dfrac{dx}{dt}.
Note that v_x can also change with time, and hence is also a function of t . When we study the rate of change of v_x we will get acceleration of the motion.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Displacement from Velocity Analytically
subsection.p: The analytic definition of velocity given in Eq. can be inverted by integration. First we multiply both sides by dt and then integrate both sides.

Let x = x_i at t = t_i and x = x_f at t = t_f, then an integration on the right side from t_i to t_f corresponds to integration from x_i to x_f on the left side with the following result.
\Delta x \equiv x(t_f) - x(t_i) = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\, v_x(t)\, dt.

statement.p:
The y-velocity of a parchute jumper is given by
v_y = v_0 \left( 1 - e^{-\alpha t} \right),
where v_0 and \alpha are constant. What is the change in y during interval t=0 to t=T?

solution.p:
Integrating v_y will give us the answer.
\Delta y \amp = \int_0^T v_y\, dt, \amp = \int_0^T v_0 \left( 1 - e^{-\alpha t} \right) \, dt, \amp = v_0 T + \dfrac{v_0}{\alpha} \left( e^{-\alpha T} - 1\right).
